respondent.name: MICHIGAN BELL TELEPHONE COMPANY, DBA AT&T MICHIGAN

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next this morning in Case 10-313, Talk America v. Michigan Bell, and the consolidated case. Mr. Bursch.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did you get -- you get (c)(2) at TELRIC rates?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I have just one small question on that.Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Suppose that there are two competitors and each of them wants to connect, but each of them wants to connect at a different point and in a different way.  Must the incumbent accommodate both if they're technically feasible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Doesn't it say something about feasible?  It -- it doesn't -- it doesn't give free choice entirely.  It says -- what are the words? That the -- the interconnection doesn't have to be put just anyplace if it's not feasible or it's undue expense or something to that effect.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you -- you want the incumbent here to -- to build the -- the orange cord and extend it to wherever you have your switching equipment.Alderson Reporting Company And what they say is, no, you -- you bring your switching equipment here; we'll -- we'll allow you to connect at, you know, the end of our facilities; but, by God, you -- you make -- you make your own connection to -- to the switches. Now -- now, moreover, you're -- you're making them -- you'll pay them for the orange cord, but only at TELRIC rates, which are not realistic.  Now, why -- why are they wrong and you're right, especially when you have legislation, the purpose of which was to encourage the independent building of new facilities?  I mean, it's clear that the Act wanted these new entrants where -- where possible to build new facilities, and not simply to glom on to the extant facilities of the incumbents.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, but the logic of yourAlderson Reporting Company case, as you described it, would also require AT&T to build out the orange cord.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me, excuse me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Extant entrance facilities I assume they were referring to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.  Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.  But if you ask for a longer distance, they would presumably have to build it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And charge you TELRICAlderson Reporting Company rates.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where would I read this? As I read the statute, the statute says the cheap system here is where they provide -- they have a duty to provide the incumbent interconnection, okay?  That requires some physical stuff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  And they have to -- they -- you have to -- you're not charged a lot for that; there's a limit on what they can charge you for the interconnection.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, somebody is going to have to decide whether if Pacific Tel and Tel is being tried to forced to connect with Maine, you know, they have to pay for a wire across country to get the interconnection or not.  That seems unreasonable. Across the street, maybe they do. My candidate would normally be the FCC or some regulator decides that kind of thing, and it's upAlderson Reporting Company to them to say whether this is or is not what's needed for interconnection.  That would be an intuitive account I would have, without having read the statute in depth. So, now what do I read to find out how this works?  What is it that distinguishes something that is ridiculous, like my California example, from something that makes a lot of sense, like they're next door and have to make 50 feet of wire.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Michigan blue --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where -- where -- 28a, okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  So, it's up to the State commission.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: This is the FCC speaking?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  And the State commission says -- they say it's up to the State commission.  And the State commission here said?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Bursch, the -- the key to your case is -- is that an entrance facility is interconnection, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You have to equate those two -- those two terms.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What do you rely upon toAlderson Reporting Company equate them?  Because the -- as I read the regulations, they -- they use them as separate terms.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Doesn't -- doesn't the interconnection -- doesn't it have to be part of the internal system of the incumbent carrier?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You say that this is a link, and your -- the opposition says that it's a -- that it's transport.  Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But the -- but the reg says interconnection does not include transport.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I have -- I've got it in front of me.  It says, "This term does not include transport."  But you -- you say it does?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, I'm talking about --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- interconnection.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is that right or --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do you read --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is there a mutual exchange of traffic when you're talking about backhauling?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can I go back to my question?  Because I haven't gotten an answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You see, I would think -- you said, well, this is an existing facility.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But my intuition would be that makes no difference whatsoever.  You could have some kind of mechanism that connects two companies. Now, half of it is a simple wire and half of it is bells and whistles.  And so, we have to decide which part is the part that's necessary for the interconnection and which part is some kind of -- well, I don't know, extra bells and whistles, and therefore, since it's not an impairment kind of problem, they have to pay full price for it. That, again, seems like the kind of job that Congress would leave up to a commission, but I guess I want you to tell me:  Who's to decide that kind of thing, and how do we decide it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't know what it is. Often, these things are not distance.  Often, a connection is all kinds of complex things, you know?Alderson Reporting Company And some are necessary and some aren't.  But I can -- can't you imagine with me the same kind of California problem arising, but it just arises in -- in kind, rather than in distance?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My -- if I'm so far off base you can't get the question, forget it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, I might not be able to get an answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You don't have to think it's that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Miller.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, underlying that question is an issue that I think Justices Ginsburg and Scalia were asking.  Technically feasible is different from economically ridiculous or economically burdensome. How does that, "economically burdensome" -- does it get considered by anyone so that -- because one could imagine, as Justice Breyer said, that a competitor could come in and say, now, build me the Taj Mahal as an entrance facility or as an interconnection facility. So, is there anyone controlling for that latter issue?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's why it's only technically feasible, because the economic burden is -- is not on the company.  It has to provide it at the place if it's technically feasible, but it doesn't pay for it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Miller, you began by saying there were two regulations that disposed of the case.  You got one.  What's the second?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where do I find that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What section are you referring to?  On page 10a?  Which one is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you do not need to provide unbundled access under (c)(3) to entrance facilities, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, what's the definition difference between entrance facility and interconnection facility?  How do we know which is which?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no, I'm not.  I want to know what's the difference.  Tell me in English what the difference is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no.  I mean, how do we know which is which?  We see some big lines and stuff in it; how do we know which is which?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's a genus and -- and the entrance facility is the species --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- in your estimation?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  CouldAlderson Reporting Company you run that by me again?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Got it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Miller, would you, before you sit down, explain what is the Government's position when an agency is asked to file a brief?  The Sixth Circuit asked -- invited the FCC to file a brief, it did, and then the Sixth Circuit disagreed.  And there was some suggestion that when an agency files a brief here in this Court, as opposed to a court of appeals, it deserves more weight.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But there may be a -- a reason to give less weight to briefs in this Court, different from the briefs filed with a court of appeals. And you've taken a different position here on -- on the issue of whether, when backhauling is included, it's part of the -- it's -- it's part of the interconnection facility?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I do not think you made that distinction below about, you know, oh, it is part where there is back -- where there is not backhauling, but where there is, it isn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Wait.  They have to be asAlderson Reporting Company unbundled elements?  I thought they never had to be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- made available as unbundled elements.  That's (c)(3).

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Your argument here is that only have to be made available under (c)(2)?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which is not unbundled?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You certainly encourage us to throw up our hands.  There's no doubt about it. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I don't know why -- why it's so hard.  I mean, I got out my orange cord, and I -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I -- I wasn't sure of if -- if it was a transport or link.  That -- that's my concern.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, continue.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Miller. Mr. Angstreich.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, I know you're saying that, but everybody's arguing about what the -- what the TRO and the TRRO say or don't say.  But I go behind that and I go -- I think the Government's entireAlderson Reporting Company argument is not based even on those.  It's based on the LCO regulations themselves.  They've cited two, which is 51.305 and 51.321.  They're not relying on those TROs in their back and forth there; they're relying on the regulation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, how do you address their point that there are two different charges at issue?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That one -- that interconnection by definition includes transport.  It's hard for me to think of how it doesn't because they've got to travel from one place to another, so --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The Sixth Circuit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, now you're reading limitation into the statute.  All the statute says is you're obligated to provide interconnection services. It doesn't say how or limit it only to things that are not bottlenecks or things that are bottlenecks.  It just says you're obligated to do X.  And that's what the agency's saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- in that regard, in all of these years, are -- you mean to tell me there is no other incumbent that has provided interconnection services at an entrance facility and charged TELRIC rates?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What happened to the unbundling rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why was the unbundling rule abandoned?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's not a bottleneck?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which is (c)(3).

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But that's -- that's (c)(3).

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: (C)(2) says you just -- you have to.  It imposes an affirmative obligation to provide interconnection -- an interconnection.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me.  That's your point, I thought.  I thought it is precisely your point that it is (c)(3) rather than (c)(2).

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't -- what I -- there's no way for you all to go to the FCC and decide what part of this thing is -- or any State regulator, what part of it is -- part of what's necessary to facilitate interconnection and what part of it is really providing the work primarily of the -- simplyAlderson Reporting Company transporting services?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What part is doing something else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There's no way to do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay, so a judge has to say, on the basis of what, on the basis -- the judge has to say on the basis of the statute, which just uses the word "interconnection"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.  But the -- the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me.  I -- I thought it was conceded that -- that none of this is -- is necessary under (c)(3).  I thought that's what the Eighth Circuit said and which is why they eliminated the unbundling obligation under (c)(3).

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, it is accepted by bothAlderson Reporting Company sides, I think, that this is not necessary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It doesn't help because it's a network element if it's in (3), and what this is, is something that's going to be needed to -- to interconnect.  If it's -- if it's in -- if it's in the first one.  And I don't know which is which, and I gather that sometimes it would be tough.  And what courts use to do with the ICC when they got into this kind of situation is a doctrine called primary jurisdiction, and they'd ask them for a brief.  All right?  So, if that's what we've done hypothetically, we have the brief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, why don't we have to follow the brief?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you agree that it has to be needed to interconnect?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The whole problem here is it doesn't have to be needed to interconnect.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It has to be needed under (c)(3), but under (c)(2), it's -- it's up to the -- to the new company to say I want to interconnect here; and -- and the incumbent cannot say, oh, no, you -- you don't have interconnect here; you can interconnect somewhere else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But wait a minute.  Does -- don't the regulations now and the commission's TRO, et cetera, say that an entrance facility is within your network?  You haven't challenged that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And it's now they --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If they're in your network --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Like orange wires and such? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In black?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Figure 4.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's not what the statute says.  The statute says the carriers have a duty to provide interconnection.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, in carrying out a duty to provide, you say that's just picking a point. Somebody could equally well say, no, it's a duty to provide means to get to the point.  Now, either of those seem equally consistent with the language.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, it doesn't say that, but it doesn't say the opposite.  And, therefore, you might have an agency reasonably deciding that to provide -- to fulfill that duty, you must provide equipment reasonably necessary to allow the competitor to connect. That's equally sensible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Apparently, you have an agency that never really said one way or the other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it used to say the other.  You -- you contend it used to say the other, and it has never, by proper means, gainsaid its prior position.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't see what the other -- I didn't hear anything that said they said theAlderson Reporting Company other.  They've said when you have wires and you're using the wires for communication, then they don't fall outside this; that's true.  But if you're using them for interconnection, and they're necessary to use for interconnection, maybe it does fall inside this.  I don't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Excluded -- they excluded transport -- all transport to the point of interconnection, where you could not provide the facility to interconnect unless you had the transport? Is that what they did?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Did they do that?  Yes or no?  I bet the answer is no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought they said, moreover, that they were not amending (c)(2), specifically.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But there are -- there are cases, I think, in primary jurisdiction where what a district court has done, anyway, is to hold the case while the ICC went and had a proceeding.  And I'm sure that hasn't been used in a long time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, maybe this is the case for it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I guess the problem I'm having is that you tell me on the one hand that up until, what, 2005, you were always paying the cost plus profit rates, the TELRIC's rates, for interconnection at a -- at an entrance facility.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, it did in its footnotes.  It said -- that's what the whole dispute is about, which is we're not changing the obligation to provide interconnection services.  So, it said it clearly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Its view --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The Eighth Circuit's decision would have been unnecessary and the revision of the rule?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Maybe the commission didn't like the Eighth Circuit's decision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It all didn't matter because, in fact, they got the TELRIC rates under (c)(3) until they changed the impairment part?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, who cared?  And now after that, they care.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And now -- now -- now the other side cares, of course.  And so, now -- now we're faced with a situation where they're just putting this in the brief for the first time, but they can't base it on anything the commission actually did?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Amd I'm glad it's right because I don't know what I'm talking about. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If we accept their policy arguments, what does that do to your main argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Because I think they've explained it to my satisfaction why this is necessary because (c)(2) requires interconnection.  Congress has made a judgment that interconnection is the mainstay of competition in this area.  So, if I accept that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It doesn't say it that happily.  It really doesn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Bursch -- Bursch, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why did they fight the Eighth Circuit litigation?  Why did -- I mean, it -- you're telling me it made no difference whether (c)(3) allowed them to do what they wanted to do and what the Eighth Circuit said they couldn't do, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Very slightly different. That's not that big a deal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Incidentally, where do you -- where do you get that backhauling restriction from?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, yes.  The --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
